name: Chris Basinger
title: Vice President of Sales; Part Owner

flow.context: Chris Basinger is VP of Sales and part owner at IOP Escapes, a luxury vacation rental operator on Isle of Palms, SC managing 64 properties with a 10-person team. His job is signing new homeowners into the portfolio — he specifically chose IOP Escapes because of their manager-inspection-before-every-check-in promise and contractor relationships. That inspection promise is getting harder to keep: they have grown from 16 to 64 units since 2021 and publicly commit to weekly physical inspections plus manager final checks before every guest arrival. They run on OwnerRez with PriceLabs for pricing and distribute across Airbnb, Vrbo, and Expedia. Chris also sells real estate at St. Germain Properties (direct cell 843-922-0222). Strongest angle: the inspection quality he pitches to prospective owners is exactly what breaks at scale — and protecting that promise protects his sales pipeline.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Chris — this is Sam Parks with RapidEye. I work with a few other vacation rental managers out on the East Coast, couple of folks in the Charleston beach market actually. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Relaxed. Feet up. Sound like a referral call, not a pitch. Pause after the question and let him answer. Do not rush into the next line.

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Rare but great. Let him talk. Whatever he says, bridge to discovery. Do not correct or pitch — just listen and ask follow-up questions.

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — TRANSITION
heard_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well, the reason for my call is —
heard_no.note: Keep it light, self-deprecating. Move directly into pain trigger with no gap.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday?
bad_timing.note: Do not push. Lock a callback time if possible. If he says never, go to last_ditch_split.

reschedule_end.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
reschedule_end.say: Perfect — I'll give you a ring then. Appreciate it, Chris.
reschedule_end.note: Calendar it immediately. Note the exact time. Do not push further.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll be straight with you. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? You can totally hang up on me if it doesn't land.
permission_fallback.note: Disarming honesty. Most people grant 30 seconds. If he says no, go to last_ditch_split.

last_ditch_split.label: LAST DITCH — SPLIT THE OBJECTION
last_ditch_split.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
last_ditch_split.note: Final play before exiting. The split forces him to categorize the objection. 'Bad time' equals reschedule. 'Not interesting' equals graceful exit. Some people soften here and let you continue.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I work with another luxury vacation rental operator — pretty similar setup to you guys, about 60 to 70 units on the coast. And the thing they kept running into is — they're promising their homeowners that a manager personally inspects every property before check-in. Same kind of promise you guys make on Isle of Palms. But when you're running 64 homes with a team of ten, and it's peak season, and you've got back-to-back turnovers on a Saturday — somebody's scrolling through hundreds of cleaner photos on their phone between properties, somebody's driving all over the island doing walkthroughs, and things still slip through. Guest checks in, there's a stain on the sofa nobody caught, or the grill on the deck is still dirty from last weekend. Now you've got a three-star review on a property you're trying to pitch to the next homeowner. And for you specifically — you're the one out there signing those owners. That gold-standard inspection promise is a big part of your pitch. Does any of that sound familiar, or am I totally off base?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after the question. Do not fill the silence. Let Chris react. The pain is tailored to his VP of Sales role — inspection failures undermine the exact promises he uses to acquire new owners. 'Gold standard' is their own language from their website. The specifics — team of ten, 64 homes, back-to-back Saturday turnovers, three-star review — are all grounded in real research. Be quiet.

branches.label: Yes / That's real / We deal with that
We've got a process for that / We handle it

warm_reaction.label: WARM — STOP PITCHING, ASK QUESTIONS
warm_reaction.say: Yeah — so I'm curious, what does that actually look like for you guys day to day? Like when a cleaner finishes a turnover at one of your Isle of Palms places, what happens between that and the guest walking in?
warm_reaction.note: He is engaged. DO NOT PITCH. Ask questions and listen. You want to learn: who reviews photos, how long it takes, what gets missed most, who does the final walkthrough, how often things slip. Every detail he shares is ammunition for the close and the demo.

discovery_warm.label: DISCOVERY — THEY KNOW YOU
discovery_warm.say: That's great to hear. I'm curious — what does your inspection process actually look like right now? Like between when a cleaner finishes a unit and when the guest walks in?
discovery_warm.note: They have some awareness so credibility is partially established. Go straight to discovery. Learn the workflow before pitching anything.

neutral_reaction.label: NEUTRAL — ONE-LINER PLUS CTA
neutral_reaction.say: Gotcha. Well in a nutshell — we built an AI that analyzes the turnover photos your team is already taking and flags damage, missing items, staging issues automatically. Plugs into your existing workflow, no extra steps for your cleaners or your managers. Basically a second set of eyes that never misses a turnover. Would you be open to taking a look sometime when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
neutral_reaction.note: He is not sold but not opposed. Give the one-liner and the low-friction CTA. Do not oversell. If he bites, book. If not, handle the objection that comes.

discovery_deep.label: DEEP DISCOVERY
discovery_deep.say: That makes sense. And who's actually doing that final walkthrough right now — is it one person or is it spread across a few of you? And what happens when something does slip through — like how does that conversation with the homeowner usually go?
discovery_deep.note: You know Jeremy runs ops and Trish is property ops manager. Do not say you read about them online. If Chris names them, react naturally. Listen for: time per inspection, staffing strain, what gets missed, how owner complaints play out, seasonal spikes. Mirror his language back to him.

branches.label: Shares details / Opens up about pain
Gets guarded / Why are you asking?

bridge_to_solution.label: BRIDGE TO SOLUTION
bridge_to_solution.say: Yeah — so that's exactly what we built RapidEye for. Your cleaners are already taking photos after turnovers. We just run those through AI and flag anything that's off before anyone has to drive out to the property. Damage, missing items, staging that doesn't match what it's supposed to look like — it catches it in minutes. The idea is your managers spend their time on the stuff that actually needs a human instead of eyeballing two hundred photos on their phone between properties.
bridge_to_solution.note: One breath. Keep it tight. Then go straight to the CTA. Do not get into features, pricing, or technical details. Save all of that for the meeting.

branches.label: We already have something for that

tech_question.label: TECH STACK QUESTION
tech_question.say: Yeah good question — we integrate with the major PMS platforms. I know you guys are running on OwnerRez. We'd want to look at exactly how your team's capturing photos today and make sure it plugs in clean. That's actually one of the things I'd want to walk through on a quick call — just map your workflow and show you where it fits. Would you be open to 20 minutes later this week?
tech_question.note: Mentioning OwnerRez shows you did homework. Do not overpromise integration specifics — frame the meeting as the place to figure out technical fit. If he pushes on integration details, say you want to make sure you give him accurate info and that is exactly what the 20-minute call covers.

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to 20 minutes sometime this week? I can show you what we're doing with a couple other operators in the Charleston beach market. If nothing else you walk away with some ideas for your turnover workflow. Worst case we part as friends.
cta_meeting.note: Low pressure. 'Worst case' framing removes risk. If he pushes back, do not force it — go to test_drive_pitch or send_email depending on the vibe.

branches.label: I'm not the right person for this

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up — what works better for you? Morning or afternoon?
book_meeting.note: Give two day options and let him pick. Lock the time NOW. Do not leave it open-ended. Once he picks, confirm and send the invite while still on the phone.

branches.label: Let me check and get back to you

pin_down_meeting.label: PIN DOWN THE MEETING
pin_down_meeting.say: Totally — how about I shoot you a couple time options over email? Is chris at stgermainproperties dot com still the best way to reach you, or do you have an IOP Escapes one you'd prefer?
pin_down_meeting.note: You have his St. Germain email from research. Offering it casually shows you know who he is without being creepy. Get the email confirmed and send options within 30 minutes of hanging up.

meeting_booked.label: MEETING BOOKED
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — I'll send the invite over right now. Really appreciate you taking my call, Chris. Talk soon.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. Send the calendar invite immediately. Do not add more info. Do not pitch again. End clean.

meeting_pending_end.label: MEETING PENDING — EMAIL FOLLOW-UP
meeting_pending_end.say: Perfect — I'll get those over to you today. Appreciate your time, Chris.
meeting_pending_end.note: Send within 30 minutes. Include 2-3 specific time slots. Reference something specific he said on the call. Keep the email under 150 words.

objection_have_process.label: WE HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 64 properties and the reputation you guys have built on Isle of Palms, you'd have to have something dialed in. Just so I'm not bugging you with follow-ups — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how inspections are working, or is it more that the process works but switching or adding anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: AGREE first. Then split the objection. 'Fully covered' means they might still take a peer-comparison look. 'Headache to switch' means they are open in principle but do not want disruption — that is your opening.

branches.label: Switching would be a pain / Timing

objection_not_interested.label: NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it — I should've assumed you'd be all set. Otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so no one from my team cold calls you again — is it that this just isn't a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls? I get it either way.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first, then split. Most people soften when you validate them instead of pushing. 'Hate cold calls' means email follow-up might work. 'Not focused on it' means park it and offer peer-comparison value.

test_drive_pitch.label: TEST DRIVE — NOT BUYING TODAY
test_drive_pitch.say: Totally respect that. You're probably not buying anything off a cold call today — I wouldn't either. But when something like this does make sense down the line — maybe heading into your next peak season or when you're onboarding your next batch of owners — the folks who move fast are the ones who already know what's out there. Would you be open to a quick look, not to buy anything, just so it's on your radar when the timing's right?
test_drive_pitch.note: Frame the meeting as future preparation, not a buying decision. Chris is a sales guy — he understands pipeline. If he still says no, pivot to referral or graceful end.

test_drive_peer.label: TEST DRIVE — PEER COMPARISON
test_drive_peer.say: Totally fair. If nothing else, I could walk you through what a couple other PM companies your size in the beach rental space are doing with their turnover photos right now. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. Would you be open to 15 minutes?
test_drive_peer.note: The value prop here is not RapidEye — it is seeing what peers are doing. Chris runs a company that calls itself the gold standard. He is competitive by nature. Peer comparison is compelling for someone who wants to stay ahead.

test_drive_future.label: TEST DRIVE — FUTURE TIMING
test_drive_future.say: Makes total sense. You guys have gone from 16 to over 60 properties in just a few years — when you're scaling that fast, adding anything new feels risky. But that growth is exactly why this tends to come up eventually. Would it make sense to put 20 minutes on the calendar a few weeks out — not urgent at all, just so you can see it and decide if it's worth thinking about when the timing's right?
test_drive_future.note: Acknowledge their growth trajectory — it shows research and doubles as a compliment. Framing the meeting as a few weeks out dramatically lowers pressure. Chris has watched the portfolio nearly quadruple — he knows the inspection load is growing.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll send something over. One quick question so I don't just blast you with a generic pitch — what would actually be most relevant to you? Like is it more the nuts and bolts of how it works with a setup like yours on OwnerRez, or is it more what other operators in your market are doing with their QC workflow?
send_email.note: Accept immediately — do not fight the email request. The question gives you intel for a tailored follow-up AND keeps the conversation going another 30 seconds. Whatever he says, mirror it exactly in the email.

send_email_confirm.label: CONFIRM EMAIL ADDRESS
send_email_confirm.say: Got it — I'll keep it tight. Is chris at stgermainproperties dot com the best email, or is there an IOP Escapes one you'd rather I use?
send_email_confirm.note: Confirm the address. Offering the St. Germain email shows you know his background. Send the email within one hour. Include a specific time suggestion for a follow-up call in the email — do not leave it open-ended.

send_email_end.label: EMAIL FOLLOW-UP LOCKED
send_email_end.say: Perfect — I'll get that over to you today. Appreciate your time, Chris.
send_email_end.note: Send within 1 hour. Subject line should reference something specific from the call. Include 2 specific time options for a follow-up. Keep the email under 150 words. End with a question so he has a reason to reply.

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — FIND THE RIGHT PERSON
referral_ask.say: Totally get it. You know — since you're more on the sales and owner acquisition side, who on your team would be the one actually running the inspection and turnover workflow day to day? Like who's making sure those properties are guest-ready before check-in? If I can get a name I'll put something together that's actually relevant to them so it's not just another cold call.
referral_ask.note: Chris is VP of Sales — he may not own inspections directly. Jeremy runs ops. Trish is property ops manager. Amy manages systems and bookings. Sean is the founder with cleaning roots. If Chris names any of them, react naturally. Ask for a direct line or email and permission to name-drop Chris.

branches.label: Gives a name (Jeremy, Trish, Amy, Sean, etc.)
That would be me actually / I handle it

referral_got_name.label: GOT A REFERRAL
referral_got_name.say: Perfect — and do you have a direct number or email for them? I want to make sure I'm reaching out the right way and not just going through the main line. And would you mind if I mentioned you pointed me their direction?
referral_got_name.note: Get contact info AND permission to name-drop Chris. If he gives you Jeremy, Trish, Amy, or Sean you already have deep research context for a tailored call to them. Log everything immediately after hanging up.

branches.label: Just call the main line / Try the office

referral_end.label: REFERRAL LOCKED
referral_end.say: Really appreciate that, Chris. I'll reach out to them and keep it relevant. Thanks for your time — enjoy the rest of your day.
referral_end.note: Log the referral immediately. When calling that person, open with: Chris Basinger pointed me your way. Build a new tailored call flow for that specific contact using the IOP Escapes research you already have.

graceful_end.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_end.say: Totally understand. If anything changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Chris.
graceful_end.note: Do not burn the bridge. Stay warm. Log the call outcome. Set a follow-up reminder for 60 days out — after peak season when inspection pain is freshest and he has real examples of what slipped through.
